App description:
Welcome to The Under: a time and mind bending immersive theater experience!
**Now with free demo: over 30 minutes of single player mysteries to discover**

For a limited time [to end of September], get a ticket to TEMPEST, a theatrical adventure led by live professional actors! Perform magic with our actor Prospero, and together create this timeless tale of love and revenge. Daily showtimes through September! Tickets ($14.99 USD) available at the in-app box office. 

For single-player fun, try out TIMEBOAT! Board a research vessel lost in the Arctic ice, doomed to shipwreck. Follow the crew and an unusual dolphin, unlock hidden mysteries, and manipulate time to alter their fates! Available as in-app purchase ($11.99 USD). 

TEMPEST or TIMEBOAT tickets also unlock access to THE UNDER, our otherworldly multiplayer hub! Have chance encounters and perform magic rituals with other players and performers to unlock and discover the secrets buried beneath the sands.

TENDER CLAWS PRIVACY POLICY

Last Updated:April 25th, 2018

Tender Claws, LLC ("we" or "us") makes interactive products for personal entertainment. Collectively, we describe our products and servicesincluding our websites, content, and software productsas our "Services." This Privacy Policy explains how we treat information from or about our users, including how we collect, use, and share information in connection with our Services.

By visiting or using our Services, you consent to the practices described in this Privacy Policy. If you have questions about this Privacy Policy, please contact us at info@tenderclaws.com

Please be advised that your use of our Services may also be subject to additional privacy policies created by the software platform (the Software Platform) that you use to access our Services, which could include, without limitation, any of the following policies:

The Oculus Privacy Policy: https://www.oculus.com/legal/privacy-policy/

The Steam Privacy Policy Agreement: http://store.steampowered.com/privacy_agreement/

The Google Privacy Policy: https://www.google.com/policies/privacy/

The Samsung Privacy Policy: http://www.samsung.com/us/common/privacy.html

NOTICE: If you are curious about our privacy policy with respect to our project Tendar, please click here.

I. What kind of information is collected?

Depending on which Services you use, we collect different kinds of information from or about you, such as:

Information You Give Us. We collect the information you give us when using our Services. For example:

When you start using our Services, we may gather information that you provide to the applicable Software Platform in accordance with that Software Platforms privacy policies.
If you buy something on or through our Services, we will connect you directly to our payment gateway.While we dont have access to the information you provide for that transaction, we might serve as a conduit of that information through our Software Products and servers.
When you communicate with us, you may provide us with information that you voluntarily provide, like your email address.

Information Automatically Collected About You When You Use Our Services. We also collect information automatically when you use our Services. Depending on how you access and use our Services, we may collect information such as:

Information about your interactions with our Services, like the duration of a session;
Information about how you access our Services, including information about the type of device you're using (such as a headset, PC, or mobile device), your browser or operating system, your Internet Protocol ("IP") address, and certain device identifiers that may be unique to your device;
Information about content or other apps installed on your device or provided through our Services;
Location information, which can be derived from information such as your device's IP addressand device settings;
Information about your physical movements and dimensions when you use a virtual reality headset; and
Information collected by third-party service providers and Software Platformsabout you through the Services, as described elsewhere in this Privacy Policy.

Information from other sources. We may also receive additional information about you from third parties, including partners that provide us information that is publicly or commercially available, and may combine that information with the other information we collect about you.

II. How do we use information?

We use the information to do a number of things that help us provide our Services to you and our partners. Here are some examples:

To provide our Services. We use the information we collect to provide you with the Services you use or request. For example, we use this information to:

Provide you with content, games, apps, and other experiences;
Create accounts and user profiles;
Communicate with you about our Services, including updates and new Services;
Enable user-to-user communications;
Provide technical support;
Notify you about updates to our Services;
Customize your experiences based on your online activities, including the content, games, apps, and other experiences you interact with; the other online services you use; and other information we collect; and
Improve and develop your experience.

We also use the information we collect to understand and improve our Services and to develop content for virtual reality, augmented reality, and mixed reality. For example, we may use the information to:

Solicit and analyze input and feedback about our Services;
Identify and address technical issues on our Services; and
Conduct and learn from research about the ways in which people use our Services.

To promote safety and security. We use the information we collect to help promote safety and security, such as by investigating suspicious activity or violations of our terms or policies and protecting our or others' rights or property.

III. Who can get information about me?

Our Services help you engage with the content in virtual reality, augmented reality, and mixed reality and others that interact with that content. To provide and support our Services, information we have about you may be shared in certain circumstances. Here is who can see information about you when you and others use our Services.

Public Information. Certain information you post to our servers or in a profile hosted by the applicable Software Platform, such as your username and avatar, will be public and visible to people on and potentially off our Services.

Service providers. We may share the information we collect with vendors, service providers, researchers and other partners (including the applicable Software Platform), who work in partnership with us to support the Services (such as hosting our Services, analyzing the way people use our Services, providing customer service, or sending electronic communications for us).

Other parties in connection with certain business transactions. In the event that the ownership of Tender Claws, LLC (or any portion of our assets) changes as a result of a merger, acquisition, or in the event of a bankruptcy, information from or about you or your device may be transferred to another company.

Consent. We may share information about you for any other purpose for which you give us your consent.

We may also share de-identified or aggregate data with others for any purpose. De-identified data means information where we have removed your name or contact information. Aggregate data is data that has been combined with other data so that it doesn't identify any specific person.

Responding to legal requests and preventing harm. We may access, preserve and share information in response to a legal request (like a search warrant, court order or subpoena) if we have a good faith belief that the law requires us to do so. This may include responding to legal requests from jurisdictions outside of the United States where we have a good faith belief that the response is required by law in that jurisdiction, affects users in that jurisdiction, and is consistent with internationally recognized standards. We may also access, preserve and share information when we have a good faith belief it is necessary to: detect, prevent and address fraud or other illegal activity; to protect us, our Services, you and others, including as part of investigations; or to prevent death or imminent bodily harm. Information we receive about you, including financial transaction data related to purchases made on or through our Services, may be accessed, processed and retained for an extended period of time when it is the subject of a legal request or obligation, governmental investigation, or investigations concerning possible violations of our terms or policies, or otherwise to prevent harm. We also may retain information from accounts disabled for violations of our terms for at least a year to prevent repeat abuse or other violations of our terms.

Third Parties that Provide Content, Marketing, or Functionality on Our Services. Some of the content, marketing, and functionality on our Services may be provided by third parties that are not affiliated with us. For example, we work with companies that help us understand how people use our Services.

Other companies may collect information on or through our Services to market to you on or off of our Services. These and other third parties may collect information about your use of our Services, including through the use of cookies, device IDs, local storage, pixels and other technologies, and this information may be collected over time and combined with information collected on different websites and online services.

IV. Security

Please note that no data transmission or storage can be guaranteed to be 100% secure. As a result, while we strive to protect the information we maintain, we cannot guarantee or warrant the security of any information you disclose or transmit to our Services and cannot be responsible for the theft, destruction, or inadvertent disclosure of information.

V. International Users

We are based in the United States, and, regardless of where you use our Services or otherwise provide information to us, the information may be transferred to and maintained on servers located in the U.S. or other countries. Note that the laws, regulations and standards of the country in which this information is stored may be different from your own country. By using our Services, you consent to this collection, transfer, storage, and processing of information to and in the U.S. and other countries.

VI. Changes to this Privacy Policy

If we make changes to this Privacy Policy, we will provide notice of such changes as appropriate, such as by sending you an email notification to the address you've provided, providing notice through the Services, and/or updating the "Last Updated" date at the top of these Terms.

VII. Contacting Us; Data Access and Deletion

If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy, or if you would like to deactivate or delete your account or access data associated with it, please contact us at info@tenderclaws.com. Content deleted from the Services may remain in backup copies and logs for a period of time.

tomflemons20 days ago
The Tempest an excellent VR experience

Reading the reviews I get the impression some people were disappointed because they were expecting a game. The Tempest is not a game, it its an experimental theatre experience that you buy a ticket for just as you would in a normal theatre. You will be in a small group led by a real actor and go through a very cut down version of Shakespeare's Tempest. For me the experience was one of the most original and interesting experiences I have had in VR. The problems of putting something like this on in real time are enormous, and sadly I have heard some shows have been spoiled by disruptive behaviour from those who could not understand what it was all about. Unless you like theatre or the experimental arts then don't waste your money but if you do you will find it amazing. If you are in doubt I recommend this review https://youtu.be/fSQD8DBLODE
Thanks to all involved for the work you put into this and am looking forward to your next production.

CacatuidaeJul 7 at 12:16 PM
The best vr game Ive ever played

I got my quest a month or so ago using my stimulus check. I had seen virtual virtual reality play throughs and loved the story. When I was shopping for games I might buy, I saw this one. Im not a fan of third person games and saw a review saying it was third person, and almost didnt buy it. Im so glad I did. I will split my review into four parts: The Intro, The Time Boat, The Under, and The Actors.

The Intro had me enthralled from the start. I wasnt sure if I should trust this strange being or if he was malicious. It was about 30 minutes long for me, but if you struggle with the puzzles more than I do it may take longer. If I understand correctly, this section of the game (which is replayable at anytime) is considered a demo and is now free, sans the rest of the game. As someone who was new to VR and did little research beyond reading reviews, it was stunning.

The Time Boat was the original show of the game. Youre on a boat and have control of time, and your goal is to experience every scene and interaction, then eventually save all the people on the boat. This took me 8+ hours and I still havent unlocked all the scenes, just saved all the characters. You can only interact directly with one character, but you save the others by following them to where they die and solving puzzles that help process their lives and deaths.

The Under is perhaps the most magical part of the game. Its the lobby and the only multiplayer area (not counting Tempest, which as of yet I have not attended). Up to 8 players can be in one instance at a time. No one can speak and there are no real goals (unless an actor is one, but thats for the next part). Everyone wears masks and can perform magic, but there is little in the way of tutorials for said magic. Players have to discover the majority of spells for themselves unless taught by another player. You can create everything from golden salt shakers to giant Keytars (the golden salt shaker is the symbol of the discord, which I strongly recommend you join) and it somehow makes the lack of objective activities in the lobby a moot point. Theres little in the way of toxic players and everyone feels like friends.

The actors are what keep you coming back. Tender Claws hired real actors, who go onto the Under in Vr themselves to entertain and interact with the players. They have their own drama, their own stories. You can attend a wedding between an actor and a player, say goodbye to a skeleton as she leaves forever, or listen to a giant crab tell you a story. Her mother will meditate with you and give out healthy snacks. Attend a birthday party on the main stage, go on a game show, or attend a rave. The actors are the only people in the Under who can speak, and they make the multiplayer part of the game. Theyll remember you and bring up old jokes, further the lore of the game, and make new players feel welcome.


If youre on the fence, at least try it. TUP is a fantastic game, unlike any other. And for so cheap, the hundreds of hours You can put into this game are worth every penny.

Developer ResponseJul 16 at 10:09 AM

We know that this is a unique model for games! The Under Presents is a larger game world with a free intro and multiple hours of content, this demo is explicitly explained on our store page. Buying a ticket to the Tempest, our live show, will give you permanent access to the multiplayer hub world and potential further live actor encounters. Tempest itself is a completely optional DLC option within The Under app. Think of Tempest like buying a ticket to a live show, theater event or movie, except you are able to actively participate and shape the experience as one of our live actors performs. Tickets represent a parallel experience to IRL immersive reflect the value of a sustained performance led by a professional immersive actor, thus specific times for shows. If you would prefer to not experience Tempest, we have a multi-hour singleplayer experience called "Timeboat" also available. This is a single purchase and also gives permanent access to the multiplayer hub world.

NighfireJan 29 at 4:00 PM
Amazing Interactive Experience!

Just entered this for the first time and had an AMAZING interaction with other players! First they showed me how to use the magic system to craft a sword, which took me some time to follow since it was a multistep crafting recipe (got it after I noticed clockwise & counter clockwise rotation are different when crafting).

After I crafted the sword, one of the other players then took me on a tour of restoring the world, brought me to the Workshop, and taught me how to craft new masks that replace your default mask. Truly amazing!

Fun to learn how to communicate using non-verbal means. You can only gesture with your hands and head in addition to snapping your fingers. Despite this, we eventually communicated enough to go on our journey and for me to learn the game's magic crafting mechanics. I have to say, the other player guiding me had quite a bit of patience, for which I am truly grateful.

The player also gave me a map while we were in the workshop, which btw is a magic map - showing our positions as we journeyed across the barren desert overworld. I held onto the magic map through our travels, which eventually ended at Stonehenge.

In the end, we both ran into low batteries (I know I did, I can only assume my guide did as well). My guide waved goodbye, gave me a hug, and was gone. Then I stood there alone for a bit, stifled with amazement... filled with a sense of wonder and gratitude for my new friend who I would never see again but would always remember when I looked at the mask she helped me craft.

...all this, and I have only barely touched the "main game," which starts on a boat where you control the flow of time. I have already seen so much, yet I haven't even begun to enjoy the main content.

I can't recommend this "game" enough. I have never experienced anything so amazing in VR. Please, do yourself a favor and immerse yourself in this strange, beautiful world.

Want a game with clear and obvious goals, instructions, and a storyline spelled out for you? Turn back now. The Under drops you into a world you dont understand, in a body you dont understand, and sets you to work untangling all the threads. If youre looking for a game with minimal hand-holding and lots of thinking, grab this now.

Youll begin to find relationships with the real world and stare at photos on Wikipedia in awe of how spectacularly conceptualized this whole game is. I really can't praise this game enough: all of it is just so unique and delightful: there really isn't anything like it in existence. The makers of the excellent " Virtual-Virtual Reality" have considerably upped the ante here, anybody who enjoyed said game should enjoy this even more, anybody who didn't will doubtless enjoy it anyway....Unless that is, you came to this place looking for generic computer game experiences. Woefully underpriced, with considerable longevity and actual live actors for you to interact with, I would be very surprised if i didn't see you there soon... evandaganJan 17 at 1:38 PM
Indescribable...

First of all - just know that this is a great example of an experience that could only exist in VR, and if you take the time to learn the learn the rules it'll give you hours of entertainment. It's best to start with as little information as possible, as half the fun is working your way through the initial confusion....

If you need a little more information; SPOILERS ahead:
The game is split into two basic modes, one is a time-loop narrative puzzle, the other is a multi-player mystery based on exploration and cooperation. There's a clear goal for the first (single-player) mode, but the multi-player mode is more open-ended. The two may be more closely linked than it seems, however, and there seems to be some kind of underlying mystery that relates the two modes, which is being gradually unveiled via live actors who occasionally appear in the game and via interactive elements and 'secret' areas of the map that have been gradually uncovered by players.

There is a growing online community around the game, and promises of future content updates from the developers, so it seems likely that the multi-player aspects will remain "fresh" for a long while, even if you manage to complete the (fairly difficult) single player mode.

It should be noted that the multi-player mode limits player-to-player interaction to finger snaps and gestures - which adds to the air of mystery, and may reveal something about the developers' philosophical outlook....

Edit, after a few months:
I'm on the fence about it now. I was initially amazed, once I figured out the basics of both the single player and multiplayer aspects of the game, and have had some really hilarious, entertaining, touching experiences, that could only have happened in VR, and probably put in more than 20 hours or so overall.

But... after a while it all just seems kind of tedious: logging in just to see if there happens to be a live actor around (extremely rare, at least at the times I'm in the have); rewatching the single player narrative over and over again in order to trigger certain events, getting aggravated trying to remember all the magic spells, or wasting a lot of time moving across the multiplayer hub area to see what's new after updates.

It's one of the most unique experiences I've had in VR, but it does get old after a while. I still think it's worth the price of admission, and keep hope alive for interesting future updates!

My #1 favorite Quest game (out of ~45)

 The Under Presents is a game of delightfully having the rug pulled out from under you, then the hardwood floor is revealed to be another rug, then you realize you're standing on the wall and not the floor, etc. TUP features the best social interactions I've had in VR, secrets to discover, assorted magick recipes, live lore-spattered actor encounters, puzzles, and more - and that's just the multiplayer part. Add in a single player immersive theater experience and you've got a sparkling cocktail of wonder and positive weirdness.

Not a lot of hand-holding on the part of the game, so if you're brand-new to VR, it may take some getting used to. But the playerbase features some of the nicest people you'll meet - they'll show you the secrets of the world and help you discover your own magic powers.

Also, don't mind the MC - you should definitely do ritual magic on the crobs.

wescotteDec 1 at 11:24 AM

This game has a lot of depth and replay value. If you're the type of gamer who enjoys exploration and minimal direction this is your game. The atmosphere and art direction is among the best you'll find in a Quest game.

There are really three main parts to this game. An "introduction" that is more linear puzzle solving, The "Time Boat" which is like a immersive theater experience. The multiplayer component that involves watching prerecorded and live skits and total exploration.

The introduction will take you anywhere form 15 minutes to an hour. The time boat will probably take you 5-10 hours and the multiplayer... Well, I'm about 5 hours in and not sure if I'm just getting started or close to uncovering most of it's secrets.

Multiplayer is interesting in that you randomly encounter other players and sometimes live performances. You can't talk (the actors can though) so you have to be creative with your communication.

The lighting and atmosphere is top notch for a Quest game and gave me a sense of presence I've only experience on PCVR thus far. I'm really really really impressed with this game.

My only disappointment is the lack of facial animation during the time boat. The MC has some elaborate scenes when you enter the time boat but after you do it a dozen times they just run out of material. I wish they were used more sparingly so it didn't feel like they just ran out of content. Lastly, some of the puzzle mechanics of the introduction were not really given a proper evolution when revisited throughout the "Time Boat" portion of the game.

However for the price of this game I'm really just nitpicking. There is an amazing world and an insane amount of content here. One of the most unique gaming (VR or otherwise) I've had in a long time.

DickDastardlyDec 5 at 9:25 AM
Worthy successor to VVR, awful controls

The Under Presents retains a very similar dreamlike art style to Tender Claw's previous title, the fantastic Virtual Virtual Reality. Environments and characters are excellent and there's an intriguing story with great dialogue and some wonderfully bizarre acts.

However, all this is marred by a truly awful control scheme. There's a technique they call "scrunching" which basically involves reaching out and grabbing the world (with the A button) and pulling it towards you. The warping graphical effect which accompanies this is very cool, but as a movement method, it's imprecise, unsuited to small movements and immersion killing.

There's also stick locomotion, but the worst implementation I've seen since Oculus Home. Instead of strafing, pressing left or right on your left stick rotates you so every time you press that stick sideways to sidestep round something (as you've been conditioned to do by decades of ingrained muscle memory) you instead get a sickening unwanted rotation of your view. (And having rotation on both sticks is totally redundant).

At least forward and backward on the left stick (kinda) work. Unfortunately they're head rather than controller relative so if you walk forward and glance around whilst doing so your avatar will stagger drunkenly from side to side.

There's also no option for smooth turning (or even true snap turning). Instead there's a hybrid system which combines the worst of both. Moving either stick to the side turns you a fixed 45 degrees (at a fixed speed) so you don't have the full control and immersion smooth turning gives you (where you dictate exactly how fast and how much you turn) but you still have the mismatch between the lateral visual flow you're seeing and your inner ear (which snap turning eliminates).

Last but not least, there's no seated mode, so if you play seated you'll do so as a midget.

Please fix this, devs! I want to enjoy your awesome experience (while the live actors are in it) but the controls just ruin it.
